entry.et: Middle English, from Old English welcumian, wylcumian, from wilcuma, noun

def.dt: :to greet hospitably and with courtesy or cordiality
:to accept with pleasure the occurrence or presence of welcomes danger

entry.et: Middle English, alteration of wilcume, from Old English, from wilcuma desirable guest (akin to Old High German willicomo desirable guest); akin to Old English willa, will desire, cuman to come will, come

dt.un: used to express a greeting to a guest or newcomer upon arrival

def.dt: :received gladly into one's presence or companionship was always welcome in their home
:giving pleasure :received with gladness or delight especially in response to a need a welcome relief
:willingly permitted or admitted he was welcome to come and go W. M. Thackeray

dt.un: used in the phrase “You're welcome” as a reply to an expression of thanks

def.dt: :a greeting or reception usually upon arrival a warm welcome
:the state of being welcome overstayed their welcome
:something likened to a mat placed before an entrance as a sign of welcome put out the welcome mat for foreign investors
